title: Angular momentum cons - disk on string new radius

content.question: A small disk can move on a horizontal surface with negligible friction. The disk is attached to a string that passes through a small hole in the surface and is held in place at the other end, under the surface. Initially, the disk is moving in a circle of radius <math alttext="0.10 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> about the hole with an angular speed of <math alttext="4.0 radians per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>rad</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math>. The bottom end of the string is then raised upward so that the disk travels in a new circle of radius <math alttext="0.20 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math>. What is the angular speed of the disk at the new radius?
